services.description: S3 is requesting permission to replicate resources in your account
services.description2: Click Allow to give S3 replication access to resources in your account. Learn More.
services.name: s3-0044523875

services.description: Amazon Kinesis Firehose is requesting permission to use resources in your account
services.description2: Click Allow to give Amazon Kinesis Firehose Read and Write access to resources in your account.
services.name: firehose-prod

services.description: Amazon Mobile Analytics would like to create roles on your behalf.
services.description2:
Amazon Mobile Analytics uses Identity and Access Management (IAM) to securely write data to your Amazon S3 bucket and Amazon Redshift cluster. From this screen, you can select an existing role or select to automatically have the required roles created for you.
To view the details of the role and its policy click on "View Details" below. To proceed with your selection click the "Allow" button at the bottom of the screen.
services.name: mobileanalytics-0045229998

services.description: AWS CodePipeline is requesting permission to use resources in your account
services.description2: Choose Allow to grant AWS CodePipeline read and write access to resources in your AWS account.
services.name: codepipeline-0044873234

services.description: AWS Flow Logging is requesting permission to use resources in your account
services.description2: Click Allow to give Flow Logging write access to CloudWatch groups in your account. This allows Flow Logging to publish metrics to your cloudwatch group.
services.name: flowlogging-0050122067

services.description: Isengard is requesting permission to use resources in your account
services.description2: Click Allow to give Isengard Full IAM access to resources in your account.
services.name: isengard-0047679719

services.description: AWS EC2 Container Service is requesting permission to use resources in your account
services.description2: Click Allow to give EC2 Container Serivce access to resources in your account.
services.name: ec2-ecs-0046788064

services.description: Amazon ECS needs permission to use resources in your account
services.description2: IAM roles help you restrict access to your AWS resources. Amazon ECS uses IAM roles in two ways. The IAM role for EC2 refers to an IAM role that grants your EC2 instances permissions to access AWS resources it needs, including the ability to connect with the ECS service to manage your tasks. The service role grants the necessary permissions for ECS to interact with resources such as Elastic Load Balancing. Learn more about Amazon ECS. You can grant required permissions in three ways: Reuse an existing role and policy, associate a new permissions policy with the required permissions to an existing role, or create a new role. By default, the controls below will create a new role or add a new policy to the role if it already exists. You can use these controls for any of the approaches. Learn more about Amazon ECS IAM policies.
services.name: ec2-ecs-0046788065

services.description: AWS Lambda requires access to your resources
services.description2:
IAM roles help you restrict access to your AWS resources. Learn more about IAM. AWS Lambda uses IAM roles in two ways. The "execution" role refers to an IAM role that grants your custom code permissions to access AWS resources it needs. AWS Lambda assumes this role while executing cloud functions on your behalf. The "invocation" role refers to an IAM role that grants the necessary permissions for Lambda to interact with event sources like Amazon S3 and Amazon DynamoDB. Learn more about How Lambda works.

You can grant required permissions in three ways: Reuse an existing role and policy, associate a new permissions policy with the required permissions to an existing role, or create a new role. By default, the controls below will create a new role or add a new policy to the role if it already exists. You can use these controls for any of the approaches. To understand the default permissions, see the policy document for creating a new policy or role. For example, the default execution role policy grants permissions to AWS Lambda write to Amazon CloudWatch logs on your behalf. You can modify the role to add any additional permissions your code needs, such as access to other AWS services.
services.name: lambda-0044690667

services.description: Amazon Cognito is requesting permission to use resources in your account.
services.description2: Click Allow to give Amazon Cognito write access to Kinesis Stream in your account.
services.name: cognito-0043888825

services.description: Amazon WorkSpaces Application Manager is requesting permission to use resources in your account
services.description2: Click Allow to give Amazon WorkSpaces Application Manager Read-only access to AWS Marketplace Catalog resources in your account.
services.name: hyperloop-0044058604

services.description: Amazon Mobile Analytics would like to create a role on your behalf.
services.description2: Click Allow to give this new IAM Role Read/Write access to resources in your account. This IAM Role will be used on an EC2 instance to facilitate copying Amazon Mobile Analytics data in S3 into Amazon Redshift.
services.name: mobileanalytics-redshiftExport

services.description: AWS Elastic Beanstalk is requesting permission to use resources in your account.
services.description2: AWS Elastic Beanstalk needs to access your AWS resources on your behalf, clicking allow will create an IAM Role for AWS Elastic Beanstalk to use. See below for details.
services.name: eb-0042752868

services.description: AWS Snowball is requesting permission to use resources in your account
services.description2: Click Allow to give AWS Snowball write access to resources in your account. AWS Snowball will use this role to import your data into Amazon S3.
services.name: importexport-0046055266

services.description: SNS is requesting permission to use resources in your account
services.description2: Click Allow to give SNS write access to resources in your account. This will allow SNS to use Cloudwatch Logs on your behalf.

services.description: Amazon WorkSpaces Application Manager is requesting permission to use resources in your account
services.description2: Click Allow to give Amazon WorkSpaces Application Manager (Amazon WAM) Read-only access to AWS Marketplace Catalog resources in your account.

services.description: Elastic Beanstalk requires access to your resources
services.description2:
Elastic Beanstalk would like you to allow acess to some of your resources to an Elastic Beanstalk Environment.

Elastic Beanstalk Environments often need acess to your resources to:

  • import or export data
  • scale your enviroment
  • monitor the health of your environment
services.name: beanstalk_demo

services.description: Elastic Beanstalk requires additional access to your resources
services.description2:
Elastic Beanstalk would like you to allow some additional acess to your resources to an Elastic Beanstalk Environment.

Elastic Beanstalk Environments often need acess to your resources to:

  • import or export data
  • scale your enviroment
  • monitor the health of your environment
services.name: beanstalk_demo_update

services.description: Elastic Beanstalk requires access to your resources
services.description2:
Create an IAM role to enable your AWS Elastic Beanstalk environment access to the AWS resources that it needs. When it assumes the IAM role at runtime, AWS Elastic Beanstalk gets temporary security credentials that it can use to make programmatic requests to AWS. Learn more.

Create an IAM role and specify policies for the role. Create a trust policy to grant AWS Elastic Beanstalk permission to assume the specified IAM role. Also create an access policy to specify the actions and resources to which AWS Elastic Beanstalk will have access.
services.name: beanstalk

services.description: Your Elastic Beanstalk Environment requires additional access to your resources
services.description2:
Create an IAM role to enable your AWS Elastic Beanstalk environment access to the AWS resources that it needs. When it assumes the IAM role at runtime, AWS Elastic Beanstalk gets temporary security credentials that it can use to make programmatic requests to AWS. Learn more.

Create an IAM role and specify policies for the role. Create a trust policy to grant AWS Elastic Beanstalk permission to assume the specified IAM role. Also create an access policy to specify the actions and resources to which AWS Elastic Beanstalk will have access.
services.name: beanstalk_update

services.description: Your Cognito identities require access to your resources
services.description2:
Assigning a role to your application end users helps you restrict access to your AWS resources. Amazon Cognito integrates with Identity and Access Management (IAM) and lets you select specific roles for both your authenticated and unauthenticated identities. Learn more about IAM.

By default, Amazon Cognito creates a new role with limited permissions - end users only have access to Cognito Sync and Mobile Analytics. You can modify the roles if your application needs access to other AWS resources, such as S3 or DynamoDB.
services.name: cognito

services.description: AWS Directory Service is requesting to create a role.
services.description2: By clicking Allow, you will create a new role based on the template you selected. You can then use this role to grant access to AWS Resources for users and groups in your directory.
services.name: directory_service

services.description: AWS Lambda requires access to your resources
services.description2: AWS Lambda uses an IAM role that grants your custom code permissions to access AWS resources it needs.
services.name: lambda

services.description: AWS Config is requesting permissions to read your resources' configurations.
services.description2:
AWS Config is requesting read-only access to record the configuration of your resources, and to deliver these configurations to Amazon S3 and Amazon SNS. AWS Config will create an IAM role that grants the following permissions:
1. Read access to your resource configurations using the Describe or List interface for AWS services.
2. Deliver configuration data to your Amazon SNS Topic and Amazon S3 Bucket.

You can also choose to use an existing role and update the role policy to give AWS Config appropriate permissions. Learn more about IAM and required role policies.
services.name: starling

services.description: AWS Config is requesting permissions to read your resources' configurations.
services.description2:
AWS Config is requesting read-only access to record the configuration of your resources, and to deliver these configurations to Amazon S3 and Amazon SNS. AWS Config will create an IAM role that grants the following permissions:
1. Read access to your resource configurations using the Describe or List interface for AWS services.
2. Deliver configuration data to your Amazon SNS Topic and Amazon S3 Bucket.

You can also choose to use an existing role and update the role policy to give AWS Config appropriate permissions. Learn more about IAM and required role policies.
services.name: configservice

services.description: AWS Config is requesting permissions to read your resources' configurations.
services.description2:
AWS Config is requesting read-only access to record the configuration of your resources, and to deliver these configurations to Amazon S3 and Amazon SNS. AWS Config will create an IAM role that grants the following permissions:
1. Read access to your resource configurations using the Describe or List interface for AWS services.
2. Deliver configuration data to your Amazon SNS Topic and Amazon S3 Bucket.

You can also choose to use an existing role and update the role policy to give AWS Config appropriate permissions. Learn more about IAM and required role policies.
services.name: configrules

services.description: AWS CloudTrail will deliver CloudTrail events associated with API activity in your account to your CloudWatch Logs log group
services.description2:
In order to successfully deliver CloudTrail events to your CloudWatch Logs log group, CloudTrail will assume the role you are creating or specifying. Assuming the role grants CloudTrail permissions to two CloudWatch Logs API calls:

1. CreateLogStream: Create a CloudWatch Logs log stream in the CloudWatch Logs log group you specify
2. PutLogEvents: Deliver CloudTrail events to the CloudWatch Logs log stream
services.name: cloudtrail

services.description: Amazon Mobile Analytics requires access to your S3 Bucket
services.description2: Amazon Mobile Analytics uses Identity and Access Management (IAM) to securely write your data, and needs a role to access your Amazon S3 bucket. To view the details of the role and its policy click on "View Details" below. To proceed click the "Allow" button at the bottom of the screen.
